The bridge ends up being a piano-centered instrumental, working within A-Minor.

Lift up your hearts and sing me a song

The only word change in the entire song. Despite the imagery of lifting up someone’s heart, Paul is still singing on the A minor chord, creating a conflicting feeling as to what the listener is supposed to feel. On the second time around, the instrumentation changes to establish more rhythm. Ringo comes in with the drums, with occasional open hi-hats on the 3rd beat of the bar but for the most part staying with a steady swing beat. Paul changes his bass riff to match Ringo’s rhythm so the beat becomes more solidified.
Sing it again

Not only does Paul sing this on the uneven 11th bar of the verse before repeating it, but it also happens on an E major chord, which doesn’t belong in the key of C major/A minor.

In fact, the riff he’s singing goes E-G#-B-D, which forms an E major minor 7th chord, creating an incredible amount of tension before resolving back to the A minor when the verse repeats.
[Verse 1]

Key: C Major/A minor

Chord Progression:
a F A d (Let’s all get up… mother was born)
G C A (though she was born a long, long time ago)
D G C E (Your mother should know… sing it again)

The verse starts off in key with an A minor chord continued from the intro, only to switch right to an A major chord via F major in between. From there it works towards the relative major of C before immediately flipping to A major, then finally returning to C. The verse ends with an E major chord (“sing it again”) to lead into the A minor chord for the next repetition of the verse, which is an uneven 11 bars.

Basically, Paul’s quite the little trickster.

Paul’s way of bridging the generation gap to days before {his} “your mother was born”.

Per the lyricist –

I’ve always hated generation gaps.  I always feel sorry for a parent or a child that doesn’t understand each other.  A mother not being understood by her child is particularly sad because the mother went through pain to have that child, and so there is this incredible bond of motherly love, like an animal bond between them, but because we mess things up so readily they have one argument and hate each other for the rest of their lives.  So I was advocating peace between the generations.  In ‘Your Mother Should Know,’ I was basically trying to say your mother might know more than you think she does.  Give her credit.
